Posts.Title: July 2011 rads Merilee jankc

Posts.Content: Jun 28, 2011 12:46PM mks16 wrote: It is hard... I didn't tell my daughter everything at once. At first, I made sure not to mention the C word... like you, I told her that the surgery removed the "bad part" and any further treatments are just a preventative. She found out though, we use the same computer and she is a very smart cookie so she saw some new bookmarks that weren't there before so she asked me straight out whether I had cancer. What I find very difficult is not what I tell her, but what she hears from others. She told me her teacher said that cancer runs in families and now she is afraid that she is going to get it. My mom passed away from cancer 15 months ago, and that is still fresh in her mind as well. She keeps asking me what she can do to make sure she doesn't get cancer... we are all bombarded with "good" advice from everywhere, to a 7 year old it sounds like I didn't do something I should've and now I got it. We do have some friends and family members that are survivors, her friend's mother just completed her bc treatment and is doing very well so there are a lot of real life examples I use to show that people can be 'cured'. Still, it is hard because we can't shield our kids from the cruelness of the outside world :/
Posts.Title: Preparing kids for hair loss & treatment Madismommy719 mks16

Posts.Content: Jun 6, 2011 12:06PM mks16 wrote: Hi everyone! I start my rads in July, but there's no July topic and not sure that one is needed. I will be following your updates until its my turn:) Coni, I went in for simulation and markings today. I think we might be in the same treatment centre? London? In any case, markings hurt only minimally, and its not like needle pain anyway. The whole appointment today went refreshingly quickly and I was out of there in 15 minutes. Make sure you're there on time, because they're so efficient, your time slot will be taken up by someone else if you're not there on time - happened to me today, parking lot was full today and took forever to find a spot.

Posts.Title: Off to the doctor today. martygra martygra

Posts.Content: Nov 8, 2011 01:35PM mks16 wrote: My situation was very similar to yours... 1 out of 2 sentinel nodes had a micromet, went for further AND and all came back clear. I ended up having radiation recommended to me anyway, because my tumor margins, although clear, weren't as large as the RO wanted them to be. I don't remember the exact margins, but my surgeon told me she felt it was more than sufficient, but RO wasn't comfortable. I opted for radiation, for peace of mind down the road, although I am fully aware of the potential damage from radiation. As for the actual radiation treatments, they were a breeze for me as well. Best wishes in deciding what will work for you:)

Posts.Content: Sep 30, 2011 05:18PM mks16 wrote: I haven't had the Oncotype testing done as I live in Canada and its not routinely done, and I am fairly young and node positive (micromet). From what I've read, and I can't now miraculously produce the link but I will if you want me to, PR- in addition to moderate-high mitotic rate will always produce moderate-high Oncotype score. As chemo was never in question for me, I didn't give it too much thought, but now, reading all your posts I wonder. The idea that "different methods produce different results" scares me.  Why even get tested then, if some TN might turn out to be ER+/PR+ when different method is used? I knew about slight variations in results, so if one IHC method returns me as weakly positive in 30% of tumour, then its possible that another method would return moderately positive, or in 25% or 50% of tumour. Not in 95% and not strongly positive. That just blows my mind. Does that mean I might be HER2 + and could benefit from Herceptin, but because of the method used I am considered negative and am not getting all the benefits I could? I am now going to read voraciousreader's links. I should've done it beforehand, but my fingers are too fast :)
Posts.Title: I think Oncotype DX is a SCAM!! peppopat mysticalcity

Posts.Content: Feb 25, 2011 05:58AM mks16 wrote: I opted for BMX because of my family history and the fact that the previous mamogram (a year before) showed all clear, and then the one prior to my surgery only showed area of mild suspicion - the only indication for follow up was my family history. Turned out to be 1.6 IDC, with areas of scattered DCIS. It has also already spread to one lymph node and I didn't want to go through that again with my other breast. US prior to surgery also showed that a lumpectomy might not get clear margins which only reconfirmed my decision.
Posts.Title: What were the reasons that you had a MX versus a lumpectomy geogal anneflorida

Posts.Content: Mar 20, 2012 01:31PM mks16 wrote: Teri, I'm 38 and having my oophorectomy in two days. I tested for BRCA mutations and it came back negative, HOWEVER the geneticist encouraged me to consider oophorectomy anyway. He made the same point as IllinoisNative, there are many more BRCA mutations that haven't yet been identified and aren't included in the testing. There was NO history of BC in my family until two years ago when my 32 sister got diagnosed four weeks after our mom passed away from pancreatic cancer. I got diagnosed 6 months after my sister. You could say the cancer suddenly exploded in our family. Because I already went through chemopause, I know what to expect in terms of physical symptoms, but this is my fourth surgery in 13 months and I can't wait for it all to be over and to adjust to a new normal. I also know, if I don't do this, I will never have that peace of mind, because its what my doctors are suggesting. Not suggesting you should do it one way or another, just hoping that whatever you do will provide you with a peace of mind and a quick return to "normal". ((hug))

Posts.Content: Sep 30, 2011 06:51PM mks16 wrote: The way I understood it Kay, percentage means the area of your tumor that responds to ER, and then there's the response rate which can be weak, moderate or strong. There's  numerous studies to be found on the internet, I believe the one I used when looking at my data was Allred score (0-8). Allred score = % Staining Score + Intensity Score I am weakly positive for ER in only 30% of tumor, so my score is 3 (for 30% percent of area) + 1 (for intensity) = 4. With your 70% (score of 5) even if it was only weakly stained, it's still 6 which is considered a high score, and hormonal therapy is very beneficial. Here's a link for more reading: www.breastcancerupdate.com/bcu...

Posts.Title: Vascular Invasion... WHAT does that REALLY mean? Nicole112 barbe1958

Posts.Content: Jan 27, 2011 05:43AM - edited Jan 27, 2011 05:44AM by mks16 Joyce, my sentinel also contained a micromet (0.25 mm). btw, more than 0.2 mm(which about 200 cancer cells I believe) and less than 2 mm is considered a micrometastasis. My surgeon said radiation might be required if they considered my node as positive. She suggested we go for another surgery and remove 10 or more, and if they all come back as negative radiation won't be required. With micromets, there's a 13% chance that cancer might be present in other nodes as well, but with additional removal, there's also an increased risk of lymphedema (about 10% increase). Furthermore, if more than four nodes came back as positive, I will have radiation for sure, which will then double the risk of lymphedema (total increase of 20%). I opted for additional surgery, mostly for my peace of mind...

Posts.Content: Jan 20, 2011 11:41AM mks16 wrote: Hi all! I had my BLMX a week ago today. It was a day surgery and I've been recovering relatively well. My right side, prophylactic MX, is healing wonderfully, the drain got taken out today and there's almost no pain and no swelling. My left side is another story. I also had sentinel node biopsy on that side, and it is very swollen and heavily bruised. The discharge is mostly very dark blood and a lot of clots. Some of them are stuck in my drain bulb and I can't get them out. Every time a different home visitation nurse stops by, she can't believe the amount of bruising that is now extending to the bottom of my left hip! I am not in too much pain, but the swelling that is right under my left axilla is uncomfortable and limiting my movements. The left breast area is also swollen, to almost an A cup size! Looking at the numbers alone, the drain could've come out today as its draining less than 30 cc in 24 hours, but the dark blood and clots scare me. I assume the swelling is because the clots have clogged up the drain portion that is under my scar?  Did anyone else have similar experience? I talked to my PS earlier this week, she thinks its too late to open up the surgery site because most of the blood has already spread all over my left side and it doesn't seem like there's any other internal bleeding. I am seeing her again in a week.  Best wishes to everyone who is awaiting surgery and speedy recovery to those who are currently recovering from it.
